children.subject:
I took 53 and think it helped with being stronger with math and quick calculus tricks that you may see in classes like ee120 and some upperdivs (have not take 126 so don’t know if it has calculus but would assume there is some within probability).

Strengthen your math bg then build up on it imo.

history.content:
<md>For context, I breezed through 61A/61B/16A, but I had a lot of trouble with 16B. While I'm on course staff for 16A, I felt really intimidated in 16B and had to P/NP it.

The last time I rigorously touched calculus was in high school, and I'd say I'm fairly comfortable (did well in HS, haven't done much since). I've no multivariable calculus experience.

This semester, I've been feeling low about myself as I was originally taking 70 + 120 but had to drop 120 because the math got too much for me (yet again, as in 16B).

While I think I should take something like Math 53 and/or Math 54 to work on my fundamentals (and get over the slowly developing fear of intimidating math-y notation), I'm worried I'll be going at a much slower pace than my peers and not pushing myself. If I take 53 + 61C, I'll have taken no upper divs by the end of my sophomore year at Cal.

My friends, knowing my grades in 61A/61B/16A, tell me that I'll be fine moving on to something like 120 or 126 as long as I self-study what I'm shaky about. I'm not convinced, however, and think that I'll feel much more confident having cleared up my calculus and linear algebra fundamentals.

Given the above, which of the following schedules should I opt for:
- 61C + 53
- 61C + 120
- 61C + 126 

I'm open to alternative suggestions as well (188/170/etc.), but I'd like to stick to 2 techs. In addition, I'll be taking an R5B and Econ 1.</md>
history.subject: 61C + 120 vs 61C + 126 vs 61C + 53
